abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Asset Management Reform
            for Morocco were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, the Bank performance was highly
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: It is important to seize
            opportunities when they arise. The operation was successful
            in large part because the proposed reform agenda came at the
            right time. Significant changes can be made with limited
            resources. Maintenance is too often delayed because of lack
            of funding. Experience under the operation has shown that,
            even with limited funding, significant changes can be made.
            Delegation to local levels and training are key elements for
            success. Initiation of the maintenance program worked
            because the central level delegated responsibilities to
            local teams, who were under pressure from the population to
            show results.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Asset Management Reform Loan -
            release of second tranche

abstracts.cdata!:
The Loan for Asset Management Reform for
            Morocco supports greater efficiency in public expenditures
            through (i) improved management of the private domain of the
            state and (ii) rationalized investment, maintenance and
            rehabilitation expenditures in education and health (through
            the development of building management systems for the
            public health, education and higher education sectors). It
            thereby contributes to the Country Assistance
            Strategy's (CAS) goals of expenditure rationalization,
            long-term fiscal sustainability, and improved service
            delivery in the social sectors. The Annex of this Tranche
            Release Document reports on the actions taken by the
            Government to meet the conditions for release of the Second
            Tranche of the Loan. Six of the seven conditions have been
            met, additional actions have been taken regarding reform of
            the expropriation law, and overall progress is highly
            satisfactory and demonstrates substantial commitment to the
            agenda supported by the Loan.

2005727.trustfund:
TF026129-PHRD-MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC
            BUILDINGS AND ASSETS

repnme.cdata!: Morocco - Asset Management Reform Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Asset Management Reform Loan (AMRL)
            Project supports improved efficiency in public expenditures,
            by helping rationalize investment, maintenance and
            rehabilitation expenditures in education and health, and
            improve public asset management, in line with the objectives
            of the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for expenditure
            rationalization, long-term fiscal sustainability, and
            improved service delivery in the social sectors. The AMRL
            will help Morocco promote a reform targeted towards: a) a
            National Asset Management Policy; and, b) building
            Management Systems for the public Health, Education and
            Higher Education sectors. While the cost of maintenance and
            asset management can be high in the short term, its return
            in the longer term is high. Thus, the project will finance
            the short-term reform costs, and help fill the budgetary gap
            during the period of adjustment. Improving public asset
            management will generate efficiency gains, and
            medium-long-term savings, and improve the maintenance of
            properties. It will also serve  to promote policy dialogue,
            partnership, and ownership, essential not only for the
            implementation of this operation, but also for the long-term
            reforms needed on overall budget and financial management.
            However, securing allocation of adequate resources for the
            purpose of public asset rationalization, and maintenance in
            future budget laws, remains the most difficult element of
            the operation, in view of the rigidity of the budget in
            Morocco. Nonetheless, this risk will be reduced as Morocco
            moves towards a medium term expenditure framework.
